column1: Historical Social Research
Migration Experiences and Changes of Identity. The
Analysis of a Narrative
Kaja Kazmierska ∗
Abstract: This paper is based on the analysis of an autobio-
graphical narrative interview with a Turkish woman living
in Germany. I analyze the process of identity changes influ-
enced by the narrator’s migration experiences. It has at least
two aspects. One aspect refers to the cultural roots of the
narrator. New experiences have changed her self-image of
being a woman. A second aspect is connected with the nar-
rator’s life course. The narrative shows how a naive girl has
become an adult and independent woman. Being a woman
is defined with the help of categories belonging to Western
culture. Therefore
column2: the process of migration is related to los-

column1: ing culturally influenced ways of describing the narrator’s
identity. As a result
column2: she becomes a stranger in her home-

column1: land
column2: but she also remains a stranger in the country to which

column1: she migrated. I analyze the narrator’s work on this problem.
1. Introduction
An autobiographical narrative interview with Hülya—a migrant woman from
Turkey—serves as an interesting example of biographical material. It enables
us to carry out the analysis of various aspects of one’s biography and social
processes that an individual can be involved in when migrating. This life story
exemplifies general features of the process of individuals’ mobility which can
be considered one of the characteristic phenomena of modern societies. Ac-
cording to PARK (1950
from the previous form of invasion—caused

column1: In my country migration is still a new phenomenon if we consider Poland as
an immigrant-receiving society. In comparison with Western European coun-
tries it is a marginal phenomenon
column2: although the situation has been gradually

column1: changing since 1989. On the other hand
column2: the people of my nation are very ex-

column1: perienced in migrating. For example
column2: since the beginning of the 19th century

column1: we have had numerous huge waves of emigration due to political and economic
reasons. The last remarkable wave took place in the early 1980s when commu-
nist authorities established marshal law to suppress the Solidarity movement.
No doubt
column2: migration gained its specific symbolic meaning in the Polish tra-

column1: dition because of its political aspect: again and again many outstanding persons
had to leave the country. In such cases
column2: mourning the lost homeland was their

column1: main experience. This sorrow has been emphatically expressed in Polish litera-
ture and poetry. It is enough to mention that the Polish Romantic artistic output
was created abroad by the artists for whom longing for the country they left
behind was the major theme of many of their masterpieces.
Political reasons for Polish migration were sometimes “overused” by those
who aimed to leave the country because for economic reasons
column2: especially dur-

column1: ing the decade of the 1980s. During that time many people left the country
asking for political asylum
column2: when economic needs were the real motives behind

column1: their decision to leave. This aspect of migration is still important and it has
always been more significant to the majority of those Poles who decided to
migrate. In order to improve their fate Poles were leaving for richer European
countries
column2: South America (e.g. Brazil)

column1: United States has always been identified in the Polish tradition as the country
of freedom and welfare. This economic immigration has been called “za chle-
bem” which can be translated as “looking for bread
column2: ” and is treated in Poland

column1: as a symbol of fulfilling basic human needs. From this perspective

Polish emigrants became protagonists of the “The Polish Peasant in Europe and

column1: authors analyzed the process of social change.

2. The Analysis of the Narrative
2.1. Introductory remarks
Biographical interview analysis usually begins with expressing general com-
ments related to first impressions after reading the text of the interview.2 My
remarks refer mostly to the first part of the narrative.
The first comment is connected with Hülya’s command of the German lan-
guage.3 According to the translator she speaks German very well; this can also
be seen in the English version of the transcription. Hülya does not have prob-
lems with describing feelings
column2: emotions
column4: let alone events of her life.

column1: Nevertheless
column2: her skill at describing life experiences with the help of specifi-

column1: cally selected symbolic categories is amazing. I particularly think of these
narrative sequences in which she tells about the official procedures which
contract laborers migrating to Germany had to pass through and about the
situation of Turkish migrants in Germany. Whenever Hülya introduces this
topic she effectively creates the image of more or less passive masses of people
who are at the mercy of powerful authorities. For example
column2: she uses expres-

column1: sions (“we were just a number
column2: not personality any more” [219]

column1: take a look
column2: a close look /eh/ what is he paying for” [257-258]

column1: left afterwards” [311]4 which seem to perfectly characterize the situation of
emigrants. In my opinion
column2: Hülya’s description corresponds with INOW-

column1: LOCKI’s and LUTZ’s et al. (1998) remarks (presented in their paper in Mont-
real) about the language used by the German authorities organizing Turkish
labor migration. Some terms like “transport
column2: ” “epidemic-hygienic reasons”

A second comment relates to the first one. I have been amazed by the narra-

consider her specific biographical situation at the time of the interview) about
her identity problems and her emotional life. In almost every narrative segment
she comments on her experiences. The commentaries serve to evaluate the
narrator’s past motives from her present perspective

column1: of commentaries in the form of short allusions show that Hülya has developed
a distance to her biographical story and that she controls it to some extent.
These remarks especially refer to the first part of the narrative

2.2. The process of identity changes
According to Anselm STRAUSS (1969) identity is subjected to constant proc-
esses of change. Although an individual tends to minimize this process and
establishes strategies for gaining a sense of personal continuity
column2: transformations

column1: of identity are an immanent part of each biography. Nevertheless
column2: the change is

column1: usually processual. Following experiences gradually make an individual
change his or her self-definitions. Changes can be marked by turning points
constituted by critical incidents. These moments in a biography enable an indi-
vidual to see the change and make him or her explore and validate new aspects
of self (STRAUSS 1969
column2: p.93). The biographical situation of an immigrant

column1: generates many critical incidents which reflect the impact of this experience on
one’s identity.
A striking example of the ‘milestone’ is found in the autobiographies of many
immigrants to America who later visited their native lands
column2: only then realizing

column1: how little affinity they had retained
column2: how identified they had become with

column1: America and Americans. Any return home
column2: insofar as you have really left it

column1: will signalize some sort of movement in identity (STRAUSS 1969
Hence
column2: past changes can usually be clearly defined and evaluated from the

column1: perspective of the present. In the case of the analyzed narrative
column2: subsequent

column1: visits to their home country play a crucial role in the process of reflective
awareness of an individual’s identity changes.
The deeper the change
column2: the more elaborated the biographical work that has

column1: to be done in order to integrate one’s experiences into more or less coherent
wholeness. Therefore
column2: coming to terms with fragile aspects of one’s identity

column1: can be a complicated and long-time process (STRAUSS
column2: CORBIN

column1: & MAINES
column2: 1984). Such situations particularly refer to unexpected experi-

column1: ences that can force an individual to face totally new challenges
column2: e.g.

column1: and physical disability. Biographical narrative interviews are very rich data for
analyzing this process of identity change and a narrator’s biographical work on
it because in his or her story the narrator reconstructs the processual logic of
narration of individual experiences. Structural description attempts to depict the social and
biographical processes rendered by the narrative (SCHÜTZE unpublished
events (HERMANNS

self image
column2: as can be seen in various segments of her interview.

column1: I am going to reconstruct the experiences of Hülya’s biography which initi-
ated the process of identity change
column2: and present her biographical work on it.

column1: However
column2: I do not concentrate on Hülya’s experience with illness; I will only

column1: refer to those dimensions of her biography that are related to the collective
aspect of her experiences connected with the process of migration. In this con-
text
column2: identity changes can be commented on from two perspectives. The first is

column1: related to Hülya’s life course when the naive girl (which appears from the first
pages of the narrative) changes into the mature woman. The second is related to
the narrator’s cultural background. Social and cultural differences between
Turkey and Germany refer to (among others) differently defined roles of
women in each society. In Hülya’s biography these two perspectives are
closely related to each other. Her redefinition of her identity can be understood
against this background.
I refer to the following stages of her biography: Hülya as a young girl
column2: the

column1: first and the second year of her stay in Germany
column2: and the next four years of her

column1: migration.
2.3. Hülya as a young girl
At the beginning of the interview Hülya remembers her childhood and she
presents herself as a teenage girl living in a typical rural Turkish family. She
seems to be a sensitive and intelligent girl. The relatively good life of her fam-
ily and her happy childhood are disturbed by her father’s illness and his inabil-
ity to work. Since that moment
column2: poverty becomes the dominant experience of

column1: her family life. Hülya
column2: the girl
column3: analyzes its consequences: no future for her and

column1: her siblings and a miserable position for her mother in the family. She realizes
that her mother will be permanently dependent on male members of the family.
The girl also discovers what is going on “outside” of her life: She discovers
that those Turks living in Germany are well off.
The poverty of her family is the first important experience of Hülya as the
young girl. This stage of her biography has distinct features of trajectory9 initi-
ated by the unexpected illness of her father. The memory of a relatively good
childhood is replaced by the experience of poverty. She gradually realizes that
there is no future for her and her family: “it was ... a calamity” (161). Hülya’s
dream about Germany has become the only positive project for the future. The
teenage girl creates the image of her life: her temporary stay in Germany will
9 Biographical “trajectory” is used here in the sense of one of structural processes of the life
course that represents the principle of being overwhelmed by outer events of the life course
which cannot be controlled by the biography incumbent. Suffering is the basic experiential
mode of biographical trajectory (RIEMANN & SCHÜTZE
change the economic status of the family. This thought has become a base of
her biographical action scheme.10 Such a project appears to be typical at this
stage of the migration process when a person creates positive plans for the
future. The plans are “located” in the immigrant-receiving society (RIEMANN
& SCHÜTZE
column2: 1992). In Hülya’s case a biographical action scheme appears

column1: very early
column2: when the girl cannot realize it yet because she is too young. At the

column1: beginning it is just a dream and as long as the project is a dream Hülya’s ex-
periences are related to intentional
column2: planned social action regarding her future

column1: life. To some extent
column2: her plan resembles a fairy tale—the teenage girl wants to

column1: become a fairy and change her family life. The more real the project becomes
the less it remains a dream.
Hülya’s plan is contrasted with her parents’ project for her life: “No
column2: you

column1: won’t go to Germany
column2: you will stay here and one day you will get married

column1: and/and your husband /eh/ to take care of you” (157-158). But soon her parents
change their minds and start supporting their daughter in her project
column2: which

column1: also becomes their plan to solve the difficult situation of the family. Slowly
Hülya loses the ability of acting intentionally. Her parents and her brother start
working on her project instead of her. The girl’s biographical action scheme is
stopped at the stage of a great dream
column2: whereas she starts to be gradually pushed

column1: into a sequence of events that overwhelm her biography.
But from the present perspective Hülya also attributes another meaning to
these experiences. The father’s quoted words
column2: when analyzed from the present

column1: perspective of her biography
column2: can be treated as a symbol of Hülya’s image of

column1: life in Turkish society. She was expected to become an obedient woman who
would depend and rely on her future husband. Here
column2: we can find one of the

column1: most important motives for her migration. As the teenage girl
column2: Hülya wants to

column1: improve the financial status of her family
column2: but after some time it appears that

column1: she wants something more for herself—she wants to become more “independ-
ent” from socially and culturally defined roles of a woman reflected in Turkish
culture. She also does not want to be manipulated as she was when her family

2.4. The first year in Germany
The “dream”11 comes true. Leaving the family is very difficult. The seventeen
year old girl enters the unknown world. The clash of her naive expectations
with the reality which she encounters is very tragic. This experience is typical
for a migrant biography when an individual having positive plans looks for a
better future and gets disappointed by the circumstances and difficulties met at
the place of migration. Instead of developing biographical action schemes an
individual may enter a trajectory (RIEMANN & SCHÜTZE
column2: 1992). In the case

column1: of Hülya these experiences are intensified by the girl’s vulnerability due to her
young age. Although Hülya had been pushed by her family to migrate
column2: she still

column1: has in mind her plan of improving the economic situation of the family.12 As a
result
column2: she is subjected to very harmful experiences related to both collective

column1: (all other Turkish workers are treated the same) and individual (Hülya’s acci-
dents) suffering. Thus
column2: Hülya loses her ability to act intentionally. Work ap-

column1: pears to be very difficult. She is forced to work in terrible conditions
column2: but

column1: same time

didn’t have money. When I came to Germany we had to take money from
other people. First

2.5. The second year of Hülya’s stay in Germany
During her first year in Germany Hülya lives as if in two worlds. One world is
her work
column2: the second world is the community of girls in the dormitory. All of

column1: them are in the same situation. In the second year Hülya loses her peer group
which has been
column2: aside from her family
column3: her only reference group. For the first

column1: time she feels totally alone. She characterizes the second year as “a hard blow.”
The first year of her stay in Germany includes the experience of hard physical
work and physical suffering. In the second year she learns how to cope with the
feeling of loneliness

column2: in the course of life
column3: lost at least some part of

column1: her sensibility and who had to redefine her identity. The statement: “I was.../eh
totally different from how I am today” (518-519) can be fully understood in the
context of the next phases of her biography.
Being different is variously experienced during Hülya’s life course. Though
the process of identity change is continuously developing
column2: Hülya is still not

column1: conscious of its character (this can be determined from the present perspective)
and intensity. Nevertheless
column2: at this phase of her biography

column1: being different becomes a “key experience” which step by step results in dis-
tancing herself from her family and values offered by Turkish society.
2.6. The next four years
There are two main lines at this stage of Hülya’s biography: her marriage and
phases of serious illness. This part of the narrative is not as clear as the story
about the narrator’s first two years in Germany. But while the ambiguity of her
illness as it appears in her narrative is the result of doctors’ silence
column2: the vague-

column1: ness of Hülya’s story about her marriage shows that she tries to block from
awareness certain aspects of her biography and that coming to terms with the
transformation of her identity is still in process.
In 1976 (four years after leaving home) Hülya gets married in Turkey. Dur-
ing these years she has been thinking about returning home: “I didn’t want to
return to Germany. I wanted to go back to Turkey. I could not imagine that I
/eh/ would endure this here for fourteen years” (546-548). There are a few
reasons that make her treat her stay in Germany as a short episode in her biog-
raphy. First
column2: she has always planned a temporary stay in Germany; second

column1: first years in Germany were connected with experiences of suffering; third
column2: she

column1: is strongly attached to her family
column2: especially to her mother (from another part

column1: of the narrative we can learn that she has always had a close relationship with
her mother); and fourth
column2: Germany is still a distant country—she does not speak

column1: German and she has no relationships with German people. All these reasons
support her decision to get married.
Hülya describes her marriage in two parts of the narrative (546-573 and
671-731) which are divided by the long story about the health problems she
experienced when she went back to Germany for a year as a newly married
woman. I do not always refer to both segments chronologically when looking
for reasons for Hülya’s decisions concerning and explanations of her failure.
There are two significant dimensions of the narrator’s experiences: one is
Hülya’s attitude to her marriage
column2: the other is the role of her mother in arranging

column1: the marriage.
Hülya’s attitude towards her marriage is shaped by the process of a gradual
change in her identity. The experiences that she reported earlier played a cru-
cial role in the process of redefining her identity. But Hülya can recognize their
meaning from the more distant time perspective—her marriage begins the
process of conscious reflection on her identity. Hülya has spent four years in
Germany but in deciding to get married she negates experiences she has gained
during this time. She acts according to well known patterns which are tradi-
tionally grounded in Turkish society—“One day you will get married and/and
your husband has /eh/ to take care of you” (157-158). So she gets married. But
soon she feels uncomfortable in the new situation because she cannot adjust
column2: or

column1: rather
column2: come back to the role of the Turkish woman. Hülya gradually begins

column1: identifying herself as a person who no longer can act according to the expecta-
tions of her traditional environment. Experiences of her stay in Germany ac-
quire a new meaning in the process of her interpretation of her biographical
situation.
Hülya tries to explain why she decides to get married. She does not love her
future husband and she also does not have a chance to get familiar with him
and develop emotional attachments. She spent this phase of her life course
working very hard in Germany. In this description Hülya presents two scenar-
ios of the young girl. The first one is the preplanned marriage of convenience
which is supported by both families. The second one is getting to know some-
body as the result of being a member of a peer group. As she sees it
column2: one of the

column1: scenarios is part of traditional Turkish culture
column2: the other

column1: Although Hülya does not miss the Western teenage life style and she subordi-
nates herself to her family
column2: it is important that she has already learned that there

column1: exists another possibility for a girl/woman to plan her biography. Perhaps as
the result of this knowledge
column2: she makes her husband accept a one year leave for

column1: Germany in order to keep at least some independence in her future marriage.
The situation when a newly married woman is leaving her husband and ne-
gotiating as long a leave as possible (Hülya prefers two years) appears rather
bizarre if looking at it from the outside. A question arises: Why does she dis-
tance herself from family life which she treats as the most important value?
The answer is related to her identity changes. Hülya does not neglect family
ties as such
column2: but she cannot accept herself in the role of a traditional Turkish

column1: wife. Thus
column2: the process of the destruction of Hülya’s marriage starts from its

column1: very beginning. The only motives to get married are identification with the
Turkish culture and expectations of others (mother and father) and these mo-
tives gradually weaken.
It is interesting to compare Hülya’s way of argumentation with the previ-
ously quoted commentary. Now she says:
I said ‘I have nothing
column2: no money
column3: didn’t buy anything either’ I say. At any rate

column1: I had been in Germany for four
column2: five years.. /Eh/ ‘When I have children later

column1: and so that I ... can tell (them) at least that I had been to Germany and that I
had bought this or that and so on
column2: memories and some electric things and

column1: household goods and so on’ (566-570).
Here Hülya uses arguments that she previously neglected when accusing “ex-
perienced” Turkish immigrants of appreciating money as the most important
value. Now she acts in a similar way. On the other hand
column2: she wants to go back

column1: to Germany in order to make sense of the hard work she experienced there
from the very beginning. Hülya devoted four years of her life to support her
family
column2: now she wants to turn these hard experiences to her advantage.

column1: After a year Hülya returns from Germany with serious health problems. She
expects that her husband and his family will also experience her suffering as
their (family) problem. But to the contrary
column2: Hülya’s duties as a wife are consid-

column1: ered by them far more important than the state of her health. As a result
column2: physi-

column1: cal suffering caused by a series of illnesses “helps” the narrator to concentrate
on her personal experiences. Hülya starts to crystallize her attitude towards the
social environment and she slowly refuses to be a part of a marriage of cultural
need. She defines it as a cultural pattern that has become empty for her. Thus
Hülya does not describe the failure of her marriage in terms of a personal ex-
perience (as she does in the case of her illness)
column2: such as lost feelings

column1: hopes
column2: unhappiness
column3: but she does it in terms of belonging to two completely

column1: different worlds. She is no longer part of the Turkish society as she had known
it before.
Another important aspect influencing Hülya’s experiences is her mother’s
role in organizing the marriage. Although the marriage was preplanned by both
families
column2: Hülya’s mother played a major role in this process. It is not clear to

column1: me to what extent the narrator’s mother was the one who supported her daugh-
ter’s migration to Germany. Perhaps she was supporting her husband’s deci-
sions. When Hülya left
column2: her mother suffered from loneliness; she also saw her

column1: daughter’s miserable state of health. When Hülya got married her mother suf-
fered by seeing her unhappy
column2: but at the same time she could not accept that her

column1: daughter would try to reorganize her life (for example
column2: Hülya’s mother did not

column1: accept the divorce). Thus
column2: the role of the narrator’s mother in her biography is

column1: ambivalent. On the one hand
column2: there was a very strong positive emotional rela-

column1: tionship between the mother and daughter but on the other hand it was
column2: in fact

column1: her mother who made Hülya accept the marriage which appeared to be a great
misunderstanding. Nevertheless
column2: Hülya tries to remain loyal to her mother and

column1: she uses various strategies in order not to blame her openly. For example
through the entire interview Hülya presents her mother as her most important
significant other; she also stresses her mother’s suffering caused by her longing
for her and then by problems in her (Hülya’s) marriage; moreover
column2: when Hülya

column1: says that her mother’s expectations forced her to accept
column2: and then continue

column1: marriage for some time
column2: she usually weakens the importance of this fact by

column1: pointing to others representing the same position
column2: for example: “only my

column1: mother and my parents/ well
column2: actually I was a victim (Hadn’t been constrained)

column1: but my mother and my parents/ well actually I was a victim” (729-730). After
saying “my mother” she immediately adds “my parents” or she says
column2: “our

column1: mothers
column2: my mother and my mother-in-law have experienced life quite differ-

column1: ently. They only accept one reason for divorce
column2: my mother or /eh/ Turkish

column1: women” (718-719). From this perspective her mother represents collective
expectations and she is not the only person to be blamed.
Hülya decides to leave her husband in 1978
column2: and gets divorced in 1980.

column1: From field notes we learn that 1980 was also the year of her mother’s death
which she witnessed. The narrator does not speak about this in her story. I find
two possible explanations of this fact. First
column2: she does not want to reveal this

column1: traumatic experience in the interview situation and suppresses her mourning.
Second
column2: she does not mention her mother’s death because of the constraints of

column1: story telling13
column2: she should explain the coincidence of the date of her divorce

column1: with her mother’s death and this could cause the need for descriptions of mu-
tual relationships and her mother’s role in the unsuccessful design of Hülya’s
biography. This would be true especially since the narrator identifies herself as
the victim of this design: “I always sacrificed myself for other people” (731).
Although Hülya cannot see any single advantage of her marriage (the only
consequence was getting the status of a “divorced woman”)
column2: it is one of the

column1: most important turning points in her identity change. She becomes aware of her
independence and responsibility for her project of life. The history of Hülya’s
marriage has become the first clear sign of her identity change. She starts it as a
traditional Turkish woman—the daughter fulfilling expectations of her par-
ents—but she quickly realizes that she is no longer the same person. The mar-
riage has become a misunderstanding because her project of life no longer
corresponds with the stereotypical image of a Turkish woman. Thus
column2: the year

column1: 1980 is a symbolic cutting of the umbilical cord in the sense of the closest
family ties (that is her mother’s death) as well as social and cultural relation-
ships with her home country—Hülya attains the status of a divorced woman
which stigmatizes her in Turkish society. I think that from this moment on she
stops considering Turkey as the country to which she would like to return.14
This supposition can be supported by the “German” line of Hülya’s biography.
In 1978 the narrator applies for compensation.15 For the first time she de-
cides to act in her own behalf in Germany. “I had to learn how to go the way

column2: to condense
column3: and to go into details (cf. HERMANNS

how to go to a labor court
column2: how you (get) a lawyer /eh/ I said ‘I have to do all

column1: of this by myself. I have to get my experiences” (741-742). We may compare
this decision with her statement referring to the end of the first year in Ger-
many: “Well
column2: everyone of us got a permit of residence for three months

column1: were glad ((she laughs)) and happy that /eh/ someone had done this for us”
(447-448). Learning to be independent is not an easy task. She receives com-
pensation but she does not achieve full success because
column2: as she learns later

column1: has chosen the wrong lawyer. Nevertheless
column2: thanks to compensation she can

column1: start living on her own.
At the same time Hülya loses her job and
column2: in order to earn her living

column1: to accept a job in gastronomy
column2: treating it as a temporary situation. This work is

column1: “A kind of work which I had never ((she laughs)) liked: In the gastronomy
column2: in

column1: the kitchen. At that time I didn’t want to be out of work any /eh/ longer. I said
‘If you want to
column2: you can do everything’. And later on when I find something

column1: better I’d get another job” (792-793). Therefore
column2: Hülya starts looking for a job

column1: she could and would like to do. The comparison of this attitude with the first
year of Hülya’s stay in Germany shows that now she gains the ability to act
intentionally and plan her life
column2: even if she is aware of constraints on her situa-

column1: tion.
In 1980 Hülya starts learning German. She decides to do it after eight years
of being in Germany. This is another step of being independent and not at
another’s mercy
column2: such as in the first year of her stay when she could not com-

column1: municate with German superiors. Hülya gradually learns how to be independ-
ent and what it means to be independent. She organizes her life and changes
from a passive to an active person. This change refers to both the “Turkish”
and the “German” line of her biography. Turkey remains her homeland
whereas she begins to treat Germany as the country where she prefers to live
right now. The fact that she started learning German in 1980 is further proof
that this year was a turning point in her biography. Hülya definitely changed
her status in Turkey. We do not know if she decided at the same time to choose
Germany as her country of residence. The idea of learning the language may
support this supposition. Nevertheless
column2: the knowledge of language enables her

column1: to change her status in Germany. She can no longer be considered a “working
machine
column2: ” having no rights and being treated as “half human” because of lim-

column1: ited possibilities of communication.16
3. Conclusions
Hülya’s first eight years of migration are a time of fundamental changes in her
identity. As I intended to present
column2: they are related to specific sequences of the

column1: 16 She presents such an image describing her first year in Germany.
narrator’s experiences as a migrant laborer. The first two years present a great
shock for her
column2: especially given her vulnerability as a seventeen year old girl.

column1: Events of this time have made her more mature and experienced. Thus
column2: during

column1: the next years the process of identity changes refers to her image of being an
adult person (woman). These changes began at the time of her migration
column2: but

column1: Hülya gradually realizes that she is no longer the same person because she
cannot act in accordance with the earlier concept of her identity. She verifies
this conviction in the course of visits or vacations
column2: her marriage

column1: mother’s death. All of these experiences make her realize that she has become
increasingly different from the expected model of a Turkish woman: “I am not
this ... good ... little mother of the family daughter of the family who has been
influenced from infancy” (927-928). While living in Germany she learns how
to cope with problems on her own. She tastes independence: “I know more
about the world” (927).
As I suggested
column2: the experience of being different plays a crucial role in this

column1: process. Hülya starts identifying herself as somebody who is different
column2: at first

column1: in her peer group
column2: then in her Turkish environment

column1: finally in German society. I have already discussed the first two aspects of this
experience. Let me now turn to her attitude towards Turkish and German socie-
ties.
The quoted self-commentary and other statements show that changes in her
identity are related to different images of women in Turkish and German socie-
ties. According to Hülya
column2: such values as being financially and morally inde-

column1: pendent and having your own life project are not accepted in the cultural pat-
tern of being a woman in Turkish society. Therefore
column2: Hülya describes changes

column1: in her identity using categories referring to men’s and women’s roles in both
societies
column2: and that is the main reason for feeling like an outsider in her country

column1: of origin. Fourteen years after her migration she neither identifies with Turkey
as a country nor with the lifestyle of Turkish society. Hülya’s image of a
woman is what motivates her own choices
column2: especially her decision to live in

column1: Germany. Hülya concentrates on stressing contrasts to give a reasonable back-
ground to the interpretation of her choices.
The narrator has passed through all the stages of a migration process: great
plans for a better life (biographical action scheme)
column2: great disappointments when

column1: dreams clash with reality (trajectory—in her case intensified by illness)
column2: a

column1: stabilization of biography (RIEMANN & SCHÜTZE
column2: 1992). She has achieved

column1: her aim after many difficulties. But in her post-coda commentary Hülya charac-
terizes herself as an “empty” person. Why is she not satisfied? What is the
price for her independence? For sure
column2: her chronic illness is one of the important

column1: experiences influencing her feelings. But first of all
column2: the “emptiness” is con-

column1: nected with the feeling of being a stranger both in Turkey and in Germany. She
identifies with German society but her Turkish origins remain a stigma. Thus
Hülya gains the status of a marginal person in both societies.
The case of Hülya serves as a very good example of a marginal person—the
concept introduced by PARK (1950) and STONEQUIST (1961). “The mar-
ginal man is one whom fate has condemned to live in two societies and in two
not merely different but antagonistic cultures” (PARK
situation may occur as a result of migration.
Although Hülya is in a marginal position in both societies
column2: her own interpre-

column1: tation of this situation is different in the case of each country. The narrator does
not accept the way in which Turkish society evaluates her status as a (divorced)
woman. Therefore
column2: Hülya chooses the role of marginal person in Turkish soci-

column1: ety. She distances herself from its values
column2: and she is not up to date to what is

column1: going on in Turkish life
column2: politics
column3: economy etc. Whereas in Germany she is

column1: situated in a marginal position of not being accepted in German society because
of her being different. Hülya represents a minority which is “partially assimi-
lated and psychologically identified with the dominant group without being
fully accepted” (STONEQIUST 1961
column2: p.121). STONEQUIST enumerates three

column1: possibilities for a marginal person to develop his or her biography: “1) assimi-
lation into the dominant group; 2) assimilation into the subordinate group; or 3)
some form of accommodation
column2: perhaps only temporary and incomplete

column1: tween the two groups” (p.130). In my opinion
column2: Hülya represents the third type.

column1: She is in-between two cultures. She has distanced herself from Turkish society
and at the same time
column2: being a Turk
column3: she aspires to be a member of German

column1: society.
The paradox of her case refers to the fact that (in terms of her present iden-
tity) she is no longer a Turkish woman
column2: and she is also not an accepted German

column1: citizen although she wants to be a part of German society. That is why she talks
about going back “one day.” But I think she will not because of the significant
changes in her identity.
